metadata.case_name: Ruston & Hornsby Ltd. v. Respondent Firm

facts.text: The appellant is a limited liability company incorporated under the English Companies Act with its registered office at Lincoln, England. It carries on business in the manufacture and sale of diesel internal combustion engines and their parts and accessories.

Ruston Hornsby India Ltd., a company registered in India under the Companies Act, 1956 is a subsidiary of the appellant. It is the registered user of the trade mark RUSTON (registration No. 5120 in Class 7 in respect of internal combustion engines) and manufactures in India and sells in India internal combustion engines under the trade mark RUSTON.
The respondent is a firm carrying on business in the manufacture and sale of diesel internal combustion engines and their parts.
The appellant was a registered proprietor of the registered trade mark RUSTON being registration No. 5120 in Class 7 in respect of internal combustion engines.
Sometime in June, 1955 the appellant came to learn that the respondent was manufacturing and selling diesel internal combustion engines under the trade mark RUSTAM.

On July 8, 1955 the appellant wrote through its attorneys a letter to the respondent and called upon it to desist from using the trade mark RUSTAM on its engines as it was an infringement of the registered trade mark RUSTON.
The defendant replied that RUSTAM was not an infringement of RUSTON as the words RUSTAM INDIA was used.
On February 17, 1956 the appellant instituted a suit praying for a permanent injunction restraining the respondent and its agents from infringing the trade mark RUSTON.
On January 3, 1958 the Additional District Judge, Meerut, dismissed the suit holding that there was no visual or phonetic similarity between RUSTON and RUSTAM.
The appellant took the matter in appeal in the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 208 of 1958.

By its judgment dated November 23, 1965 the High Court held that the use of the word RUSTAM by the respondent constituted infringement of the appellant's trade mark RUSTON and the respondent should be prohibited from using the trade mark RUSTAM. But the High Court proceeded to hold that the use of the words RUSTAM INDIA was not an infringement because the plaintiff's engines were manufactured in England and the defendant's engines were manufactured in India. The suffix India would be a sufficient warning that the engine sold was not a RUSTON engine manufactured in England and the respondent may be permitted to use the combination RUSTAM INDIA.

legal_issues.text: Whether the use of the words RUSTAM INDIA by the respondent constitutes infringement of the appellant's registered trade mark RUSTON.
Distinction between an infringement action and a passing off action.

petitioner_arguments.text: The use of RUSTAM by respondent infringes registered trade mark RUSTON; extended to RUSTAM INDIA.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 21 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940

respondent_arguments.text: RUSTAM INDIA is not an infringement of RUSTON as the words RUSTAM INDIA was used; suffix INDIA distinguishes as engines manufactured in India vs England.

court_reasoning.text: Section 21 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940 gives the registered proprietor the exclusive right to the use of the trade mark, infringed by use of a mark so nearly resembling it as to be likely to deceive or cause confusion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The distinction between infringement action (statutory right based on registration, no need to prove deception if mark identical or colourable imitation) and passing off action (based on probability of confusion from get-up).

court_reasoning.text: High Court found deceptive resemblance between RUSTON and RUSTAM; respondent did not appeal that finding. If deceptively similar, adding INDIA is of no consequence for infringement action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In infringement, once mark shown to offend, user cannot escape by distinguishing outside the mark itself.

court_reasoning.text: Test of infringement where marks similar: likelihood of confusion or deception, same as in passing off.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statutory protection absolute; infringement by exact imitation or near resemblance likely to deceive.

holdings.text: Use of RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA constitutes infringement of registered trade mark RUSTON; appellant entitled to permanent injunction.
In infringement action, adding words like INDIA to deceptively similar mark does not prevent infringement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Saville Perfumery Ltd. v. June Perfect Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Statute-law on infringement based on passing-off idea but absolute protection; infringement by use of resembling mark likely to deceive.
In equity, injunction for passing off immaterial whether defendant fraudulent.

statutes_cited.name: Trade Marks Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Section 21 defines infringement by use of identical or nearly resembling mark likely to deceive; action statutory, dependent on registration.

statutes_cited.name: Trade Marks Act, 1938
statutes_cited.relevance: Infringement by exact imitation or resembling mark likely to deceive (UK Act referred for principle).

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Ruston Hornsby India Ltd. registered under it.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment modified. Permanent injunction granted restraining respondent from infringing trade mark RUSTON by using RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA on engines, machinery, accessories. Nominal damages of Rs. 100/- awarded. Order to deliver price-lists, bills, invoices, advertising material bearing RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA.
outcome.relief_granted: Permanent injunction against use of RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA; nominal damages Rs. 100/-; delivery up of infringing materials.

key_quotes.text: "If the respondents trade mark is deceptively similar to that of the appellant the fact that the word INDIA is added to the respondents trade mark is of no consequence and the appellant is entitled to succeed in its action for infringement of its trade mark."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on why RUSTAM INDIA still infringes.

key_quotes.text: "In an infringement action the issue is: Is the defendant using a mark which is the same as or which is a colourable imitation of the plaintiffs registered trade mark?"
key_quotes.speaker: court
